intro: Ophiorrhiza rhododictyon, commonly known as the red-veined mangrove, is a species of flowering plant in the family Rhizophoraceae. It is a small, shrub-like tree that typically grows in brackish water environments, such as mangrove forests. The plant is characterized by its distinctive red veins on the leaves, which give it its common name. It has specialized root systems that allow it to thrive in saline and waterlogged soils. Ophiorrhiza rhododictyon plays an important ecological role in coastal ecosystems by stabilizing shorelines and providing habitat for various marine and terrestrial organisms.
